Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Cyber Identity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This funding establishes a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at North Carolina A&T University. Undergraduate students from across the nation will participate in summer research focused on cyber identity. The digitization of our everyday lives has increased the need to establish safer and more secure ways to provide accurate identification for online transactions and to protect personal information. The students will participate in research projects that investigate methods to help users control the security of their digital identity. Cyber identity research and its applications hold great promise for establishing trusted online identity, reducing identity theft, and ensuring privacy. The challenges of cyber identity research provide an exciting opportunity to bring together faculty researchers and students to investigate fundamental principles and design strategies in computing systems to develop real-world, secure systems that we can all trust. This project is co-funded by the Cyber Corps (R): Scholarship for Service Program.

The research projects explored in this site focus on open research challenges in the areas of computational frameworks, attacks on cyber identity, and mitigation strategies. Impacts of the research include an advanced computational framework for numerical and conceptual identities, extended webIDs for online identity and login, new approaches to alleviate replay attacks in Biometric based Access Control Systems, improved analytics for authorship analysis of code associated with malware, and enhanced cyber attack detection and attribution to attackers. The students will use of state-of-the art facilities and devices and work with faculty mentors with significant expertise in cyber identity research. The site will focus on recruiting under-represented minorities, particularly drawing on a large network of colleges in the region around the host institution. The students will participate in professional development activities that make them more aware of graduate school and professional aspects of a computing career. The project should contribute to the development of a diverse scientific workforce with expertise in areas critical to national security in the evolving global society of the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this program is to provide an opportunity for a diverse group of talented undergraduate students to participate in research projects on cyber identity. The main objectives of the REU program are as follows:

  • To introduce REU students to the theoretical foundations and practical application of cyber identity research.
  • To train students in research and communication skills, including literature review, new approaches to solve open problems, creative and independent thinking, experimental design and interpretation, and effective oral and written communication.
  • To motivate the students in computer science (CS) to pursue research by exposing them to the intellectual excitement of research in CS and cyber identity and explaining professional development.
  • To inspire students to carry out graduate studies and research careers in CS or related disciplines with a wide variety of means, including career advisement and seminars, participation in professional meetings and field trips, and social events.

 

The REU program provides an opportunity for a diverse group of talented undergraduate students to participate in research projects on cyber identity. During the summer, we provide short course, seminar, individual/group meetings, social events, field trips to help students to conduct the research, and develop future career in research. Undergraduate students gain research experience by engaging in projects such as establishing an identity-theory framework, exploitating WebIDs for multiple identities, applying authorship analysis, mitigating biometric-based replay and presentation attacks, identifying web clients through behavior characterization, and detecting cyber threats by matching patterns of user behavior.

The intellectual merit of this REU program is exhibited in each individual research project in the area of cyber identity, which is a research field of national priority. By engaging a diverse pool of talented undergraduate students in developing large-scale, high-performance, user-centered, and intelligent cyber identity solutions, the research activities in this proposal contribute to the understanding of the fundamental theory, principles, and techniques in identity science, cyber security, data science, machine learning, and biometrics. Immediate impacts of our research activities include: (1) an advanced computational framework for numerical and conceptual identities; (2) extended WebIDs for online identity and login; (3) new approaches to alleviate replay and presentation attacks in Biometric based Access Control Systems (BACS); (4) improved analytics for authorship analysis; (5) enhanced cyber attack detection and attribution to attackers, which leads to improved cyber security.

The REU program helps create a brigade of young scientists in CS and advances discovery and understanding while promoting learning. This program makes a special effort to recruit females and minority students from institutions with limited research opportunities in CS. Students' educational experiences and research results are disseminated through websites and other media as well as student publications and presentations. This program trains the REU students in cyber identity and has both research and education impact. An understanding of cyber identity is a prerequisite for developing trusted identity frameworks. Such frameworks and improved analytics for cyber identity ensure protection from cyber threats and a lower cost for cyber security. The proposed program allows a diverse pool of highly motivated students studying at institutions with limited research opportunities in CS to develop valuable attributes, including self-confidence, creative thinking, and independent problem solving skills. Special consideration is given to underrepresented minorities and females.
